oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:title: Ralph Emery interviews Tom T. Hall and Earl Scruggs Parts 1, 2 and 3
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:description: Recording is from Ralph Emery's (entertainer) interview of Tom T. Hall (performer) and Earl Scruggs for the Ralph Emery Show. The recording is from an unknown date.
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:creator: Ralph Emery; Tom T. Hall; Earl Scruggs
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dcterms:tableOfContents: (00:03) Tom T. Hall and Earl Scruggs perform a radio spot for the Ralph Emery Show -- (00:19) Ralph Emery introduces Hall and Scruggs -- (02:10) Emery asks Hall and Scruggs to reflect on "Roll in My Sweet Baby's Arms" from the Roll In My Sweet Baby's Arms album -- (04:06) Emery jokes about Hall and Scruggs' names while introducing "There Ain't No Country Music on This Jukebox" -- (06:09) Emery invites Hall to introduce Barbara Mandrell's "Til You're Gone," and Emery recalls how Hall taught Mandrell's son how to play poker -- (07:07) Emery asks Scruggs to introduce Waylon Jennings and Willie Nelson's "Just to Satisfy You" -- (07:44) Emery reflects on Smithville, and Hall discusses how he has a bear story -- (08:47) Hall reflects on how he does not tour during winter, and Hall and Scruggs discuss how Hall called Scruggs to collaborate -- (11:22) Emery invites Hall and Scruggs to reflect on "Song of the South,;" additionally, Scruggs praises the Oak Ridge Boys -- (13:51) Emery invites Hall to reflect on David Frizzell and Shelly West; additionally, Emery discusses his favorites for his pick for the Duo of the Year Award -- (16:41) Emery and Hall discuss how a number of people praise "Lonesome Valley;" additionally, Emery, Hall and Scruggs say goodbye -- (18:00) Emery introduces the Ralph Emery Show, Hall and Scruggs -- (19:23) Emery reflects on the public domain song: "Wishful Thinkin,'" and Hall discusses how he modified the song -- (21:34) Emery asks Scruggs about the status of the Earl Scruggs Review -- (22:35) Emery and Scruggs discuss the Mercury recording of "The Foggy Mountain Breakdown," and Emery invites Scruggs to reflect on how "The Foggy Mountain Breakdown" was the theme for Bonnie and Clyde -- (26:57) Emery invites Hall to reflect on how he was greeted by a bear at his cabin -- (29:08) Hall reflects on being an engineer and a performer at the same time for a studio program -- (30:35) Emery inquires about Scruggs' longevity in his career -- (31:55) Emery inquires as to whether or not Hall had written "Engineers Don't Wave From the Trains Anymore" -- (34:01) Emery, Hall and Scruggs say goodbye -- (34:45) Tom T. Hall radio spot for introduction for the Ralph Emery, and Emery asks Scruggs to introduce "Take Me to the Country" -- (35:47) Emery invites Scruggs to reflect on how he introduced Hall to "No Expectations;" additionally, Hall and Scruggs discuss the songs that they did not release on the album -- (37:16) Emery asks Scruggs about his vocal contribution to the album, and Emery asks Scruggs to reflect on Michael Card and Bonnie Galley (Unconfirmed) -- (39:09) Emery asks Hall to recall the first time he met Scruggs -- (43:14) Emery asks Scruggs to recall his first memory of Hall -- (45:34) Scruggs praises Ricky Skaggs and "Cryin' My Heart Out Over You" -- (46:11) Emery inquires about Scruggs' twenty-one year career with Lester Flatt -- (50:12) Emery, Hall, and Scruggs show their appreciations and say goodbye
